question.text:
The addition of HBr to 1-butene gives a mixture of products x, y and z

The mixture consists of

options.text: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi></math> as major and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">z</mi></math> as minor products

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi></math> as major, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">z</mi></math> as minor products

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi></math> as minor, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">z</mi></math> as major products

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi></math> as minor and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">z</mi></math> as major products

solution.text:
The alkene is unsymmetrical, hence will follow Markownikoff's rule to give major product.

since, y contains, a chiral carbon, it exists in two enantiomers (x and y) which are mirror images of each other.
